title: Community messaging issues

milestone.title: 1.23.0 - Alpha
milestone.description:
"This release should feature:

- Onboarding:
  Allow a user to restore their account using a seedphrase

- Syncing
  Allow a user to syncing/pair two unpaired devices

- Communities
  User facing token gating functionality

- General polish:
  further polish of messaging/communities/onboarding"

body:
### ISSUE 1 Community channel appears with delay for newly joined member

**Preconditions**: User A and User B are mutual contacts

Bug is not reproducible every time. Sometimes up to 4 tries are needed for reproduction

**Steps:**

1. Create community by User A (I've been testing on open communities)
2. Send invite to User B
3. Create new community channel by User A 
5. Generate some message history in channel
6. By User B open 1-1 chat with User A (link from User A should be displayed but keep in mind about ISSUE ???)
7. Open community link by User B
8. Tap Join community by User B
9. See if community channel is displayed for User B

**Actual result:** channel appears with delay up to 2-5 minutes.

**Expected result:** channel is displayed right after community join.


https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/97245802/212356668-59fcfb20-6b98-416f-832e-f8b75dc2cf18.mp4

[community_owner_logs.zip](https://github.com/status-im/status-mobile/files/10412861/community_owner_logs.zip)

[new_member_logs.zip](https://github.com/status-im/status-mobile/files/10412863/new_member_logs.zip)

### Additional Information

- Status version: nightly 
- Operating System: Android, iOS

### ISSUE 3 Messages sent in channel while being offline are not sent after coming back online. They stuck in sending status.

Seems that bug has been introduced by https://github.com/status-im/status-mobile/pull/14779 as I was not able to reproduce in develop. 

**Steps:**

1. Enable flight mode
2. Send some messages in community channel while being offline
3. Disable flight mode
4. See if messages are delivered after returning online

**Actual result:** messages stuck in "sending" status and never sent later. 

**Expected result:** messages should be sent and delivered after returning online

below video and logs are from PR build as it has not been yet merged into develop at the moment of testing. 

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/97245802/212707655-f0ec0fe3-35ef-4b4c-9ad9-c408d060534c.mp4

[receiver.zip](https://github.com/status-im/status-mobile/files/10426872/receiver.zip)
[sender.zip](https://github.com/status-im/status-mobile/files/10426873/sender.zip)

ISSUE 3 is also relevant for deleting messages:
If UserA deletes messages while UserB is offline, some messages will remain in the chat for UserB when returning online.

re: issue 3

One observation: if you turn connection off and send the message right away, wait 3-4 mins, turn it back on - then message will not be re-sent. But If you turn connection off and wait 3-4 mins, then send the message while offline, wait another 3-4 mins and turn connection back on - the message will be eventually re-sent.

Steps to repro:
1. Enable flight mode
2. Send messages A in community channel while being offline right away
3. wait 3-4 mins
4. Send messages B in community channel while being offline
5. wait 3-4 mins
6. Disable flight mode
7. wait 3-4 mins
8. see that message B is delivered, message A is not

So resending is in place, it just doesn't pick messages which are sent right after loosing connection (1-2 mins or so)

@cammellos @richard-ramos 
It looks like it takes some time on waku side to "realise" that connection is lost, and this causes issue 3 when messages are sent in public chats and unencrypted communities (because waku still dispatches `EventEnvelopeSent` although there is no connection).
cc @siphiuel as he was looking into something similar

Interesting. Taking a wild guess, could be related to this code https://github.com/waku-org/go-waku/blob/57d707ff506819c0c20623883fcf73e84ef13ccd/waku/v2/node/keepalive.go#L32 ? Keep-alive needing some time to disconnect peers.

@siphiuel, I commented out `go w.startKeepAlive(ctx, w.opts.keepAliveInterval)` and it still took about 2 mins on waku side to notice that connection is lost. 
If that's a proper way to verify that `startKeepAlive` is unrelated to the issue.

I see. Right, that code is there in the first place to prevent inactive peer disconnects.

Could be that keepAlive is a sort of early-warning mechanism that fails because we have a 10 sec default keepAlive interval (if i read that correctly in status-go), plus we multiply by 3 to get `sleepDetectionInterval`.

If you comment it away, then it makes things worse (it'll never be able to close peer itself), and in that case it's something that libp2p does on a lower level (peer disconnects in 2 mins). Maybe decreasing the `keepAliveInterval` can help.

@siphiuel I think the issue here is that we don't have acknowledgements from other peers, as we did in waku-1, so messages are marked as sent if the *leave* the node, but it could be that we are writing on a dead connection that we haven't realized is dead (i.e an half open socket).

It would be nice to get acknowledgements from other peers if possible, did we look into it @richard-ramos ?
Meaning - strange, then it seems like `Network().ClosePeer()` is not enough.
@siphiuel well, regarding 2 mins: it seems that this time is around that time or even longer on iOS simulator when on real iOS device it might be under 1 minute. So it depends

@siphiuel just double-checked: if there are zero peers after loosing connection then messages is resent later, otherwise it is lost. So this is a bit more precise way to determine what happens than just waiting for 2 mins :)

> @cammellos It would be nice to get acknowledgements from other peers if possible, did we look into it?

AFAIK with current implementation, this is only possible with lightpush, since you get a response indicating that the node you chose to broadcast a message received your request. I'll take a look at go-libp2p-pubsub to see how the Publish function works in case of disconnection.

Seems to me like if go-libp2p-pubsub cannot send a message, nothing happens?
https://github.com/libp2p/go-libp2p-pubsub/blob/master/comm.go#L181-L186

EDIT:
So, `stream.Reset()` and `stream.Close()` are executed. I guess this does not remove the peers from the list of connected peers. I'll continue investigating...

So i followed the code from https://github.com/status-im/status-go/blob/develop/vendor/github.com/libp2p/go-libp2p-pubsub/comm.go#L170-L175 and saw that if the node has an active tcp connection, and then the machine is disconnected, it will still attempt to send data via the connection and not fail, so it's getting buffered somewhere...(perhaps at OS level).  The peer only gets disconnected when we try to read data from it (which happens with the keep-alive loop).

I see in go-libp2p-pubsub that `s network.Stream` has a [`SetWriteDeadline`](https://pkg.go.dev/net#TCPConn.SetWriteDeadline) function available. Perhaps we can try to force a small timeout there and see how it behaves? 


> @cammellos: I think the issue here is that we don't have acknowledgements from other peers, as we did in waku-1
> It would be nice to get acknowledgements from other peers if possible, did we look into it @richard-ramos ?

I guess that would involve doing a fork of go-libp2p-pubsub and making changes in the protocol? looking at https://github.com/libp2p/specs/blob/master/pubsub/README.md#stream-management I don't see guidance in the pubsub RFC on how replying to RPC messages is handling.

cc: @Tanguy and @jm-clius for ideas!

I ran into a problem with creating group chats.
I tried to create group chats on one of my devices - Huawei, inviting to those groups two other devices - Pixel and iPhone.

Groups were created on the admin side (Huawei), but the invited members never received them.

I checked the Huawei date&time settings and found that the date and time were set **manually** there, and the time was indeed a little behind the other two devices (~30 seconds).

I changed the setting to `set automatically` and that fixed the problem - groups created on Huawei started showing up on other devices.

Logs before changing the settings 
[Group admin (Huawei) geth.log](https://github.com/status-im/status-mobile/files/11061038/geth.log)
[Member (Pixel) geth.log](https://github.com/status-im/status-mobile/files/11061047/geth.log)



Question: should we (and can we) somehow handle this behavior if the time is set manually on a device? Do we need a separate issue for this?
